snippet: Researchers in Panama reported that after three years, forest areas with lianas had 76 percent less biomass than plots that had been cleared of vines.
abstract: Study in journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences finds woody climbing vines called lianas contribute to 76 percent less biomass per year in forests they inhabit by inhibiting tree growth; occurrence reduces forest's ability to store carbon and slow climate change.

keywords.value: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
keywords.name: organizations

lead_paragraph: Researchers in Panama reported that after three years, forest areas with lianas had 76 percent less biomass than plots that had been cleared of vines.

headline.print_headline: Ecology: Study Quantifies Liana Vines’ Threat to Forests
headline.main: Study Quantifies Liana Vines’ Threat to Forests
